data.title: Markdown pane isn't focused
data.body: When you hit `ctrl-m` on a Markdown document, a new pane appears but it's not focused. You have to hit `ctrl-tab` to focus it so you can scroll with your keyboard or close it with `meta-w`.

data.title: Swap ag for nak
data.body:
Picking up on an idea from _way back_ [in Janauary](https://github.com/github/atom/issues/129).

Personally, I believe mucking around with node-gyp and compiling native entities should be kept to a minimum. Especially when coming up with a cross-platform application, cross-platform features need to be respected. 

Among other things, `ag` doesn't really work too well on Windows. I would like to suggest switching to [`nak`](https://github.com/gjtorikian/nak) if possible.
### Advantages
- Cross platform (you got Node, you got `nak`)
- Streams results. This is key, I think. Think of how search results populate in through Sublime Text. `ag` (and currently, Atom) just dump a blob of search results. That's a wonky UX.
- Search results are _in order_. Whereas `ag` returns results like this:  
      `./vendor/themes/Zenburnesque.tmTheme`  
      `./vendor/underscore.js`  
  `nak` knows that you should search and list your current dir, before advancing alphabetically through the subdirs.
### Disadvantages

Over the last few weeks, `ag` got faster. I shaved 500ms off of `nak` in comparison searches, but it's still about four times slower. Here are some numbers:
- Searching for the word "silver" in all of atom (13300 files) 
  - `ag`: 0.240 seconds
  - `nak`: 1.516 seconds
- Searching for the word "function" in all of atom (13300 files) 
  - `ag`: 0.602 seconds
  - `nak`: 1.989s seconds
- Searching for the letter "v" in my dev dir (69329 files) 
  - `ag`: 10.42 seconds
  - `nak`: 13.37 seconds

Can `nak` be faster? Actually, yes. Since `console.log` is blocking, every time I stream back  a chunk of results I'm holding up the processing. If I drop the streaming results I can improve the speed a little more, but I kind of prefer the stream.
### Other search-y stuff

`ag` and `nak` both allow for whole word matching, case-sensitivity, non-regexps, _e.t.c._. Atom needs to figure out a way to do these things.

Also, `nak` supports find _and replace_ in files. You can also filter on the file level, _e.g._, `--ignore *.js` excludes JS files, `--include *.less` only checks LESS files. 
#### More ?!

`nak` can also be used to populate the fuzzy-file list. It takes around 300ms to get all the files in the Atom dir. Unfortunately, that's not in this PR, because I couldn't get it to work properly.

data.title: Atom is unresponsive after opening contributions.scss
data.body:
Every time I open `app/assets/stylesheets/github/contributions.scss` the app becomes unresponsive -- except I can Quit. No amount of waiting seems to allow for it to right itself. I've opened the inspector before opening the file to try to catch some hint of what's going on, but either the app becomes unresponsive before reporting errors or nothing actually errors out.

_Note: This is accompanied with a CPU spike where the Atom Helper process is consuming 100%._

Not sure if this is related to #150 as I am able to load large large files from `vendor/assets` just fine.

data.title: Quitting Atom crashes when building with debug build of CEF
data.body:
To reproduce this problem:
1. Open atom.gyp, change all `cef/Release/libcef.dylib` to `cef/Debug/libcef.dylib`
2. rake build
3. Run Atom and press Cmd+Q to quit

Atom then crashes with stack trace:

```
[0312/211955:FATAL:browser_host_impl.cc(1005)] Check failed: CEF_CURRENTLY_ON(content::BrowserThread::UI). 
0   libcef.dylib                        0x0107bbef base::debug::StackTrace::StackTrace() + 63
1   libcef.dylib                        0x0107bb8b base::debug::StackTrace::StackTrace() + 43
2   libcef.dylib                        0x010c824c logging::LogMessage::~LogMessage() + 76
3   libcef.dylib                        0x010c6d3b logging::LogMessage::~LogMessage() + 43
4   libcef.dylib                        0x0258d80c CefBrowserHostImpl::DestroyBrowser() + 268
5   libcef.dylib                        0x02717595 -[CefBrowserHostView dealloc] + 69
6   libobjc.A.dylib                     0x914378ff -[NSObject release] + 47
7   libobjc.A.dylib                     0x91421442 (anonymous namespace)::AutoreleasePoolPage::pop(void*) + 490
8   CoreFoundation                      0x93657083 _CFAutoreleasePoolPop + 51
9   Foundation                          0x9711b23d -[NSAutoreleasePool drain] + 122

11  libcef.dylib                        0x010d8adb base::mac::ScopedNSAutoreleasePool::~ScopedNSAutoreleasePool() + 43
12  libcef.dylib                        0x0030b727 scoped_ptr<base::mac::ScopedNSAutoreleasePool>::reset(base::mac::ScopedNSAutoreleasePool*) + 87
13  libcef.dylib                        0x0030b66b content::ContentMainRunnerImpl::Shutdown() + 715
14  libcef.dylib                        0x025db030 CefContext::FinalizeShutdown() + 160
15  libcef.dylib                        0x025da204 CefContext::Shutdown() + 676

18  Atom                                0x000c8f67 CefShutdown() + 18
19  Atom                                0x000ad162 -[AtomApplication applicationWillTerminate:] + 240
20  Foundation                          0x9711fc52 __57-[NSNotificationCenter addObserver:selector:name:object:]_block_invoke_0 + 49

25  AppKit                              0x91d64e19 -[NSApplication terminate:] + 2420
26  libobjc.A.dylib                     0x914375d3 -[NSObject performSelector:withObject:] + 70
27  AppKit                              0x91c27bd2 -[NSApplication sendAction:to:from:] + 436
28  AppKit                              0x91d643dc -[NSMenuItem _corePerformAction] + 529
29  AppKit                              0x91d6406b -[NSCarbonMenuImpl performActionWithHighlightingForItemAtIndex:] + 163
30  AppKit                              0x91d636f4 -[NSMenu _performActionWithHighlightingForItemAtIndex:sendAccessibilityNotification:] + 79
31  AppKit                              0x91d636a0 -[NSMenu _performActionWithHighlightingForItemAtIndex:] + 48
32  AppKit                              0x91d62ba5 -[NSMenu performKeyEquivalent:] + 306
33  Atom                                0x000ad222 -[AtomApplication sendEvent:] + 137
34  AppKit                              0x91b3172c -[NSApplication run] + 951
35  libcef.dylib                        0x0104ca5e base::MessagePumpNSApplication::DoRun(base::MessagePump::Delegate*) + 350

37  libcef.dylib                        0x010e1c12 MessageLoop::RunInternal() + 290

Trace/BPT trap: 5
```

The CefShutdown requires running under the UI thread, and will cause assertion otherwise. This check doesn't not run under Release build.

I'm not sure why cefclient doesn't suffer from this problem.

data.title: Why a dev branch?
data.body: This was eating at me a bit and I didn't see it documented, so I figured I'd ask. `master` means "the head of development" on pretty much every other active repository we have. Why not a `release` branch?

data.title: Overly long line leads to cursor/line mismatch.
data.body:
I pasted in a paper abstract to a Markdown document and it appears that the line is so long that it causes a mismatch of a line between the cursor position and the actual line being edited. When I split the line, which honestly makes it a bit easier to read anyway, this goes away. 

Switching between Softwrap and non-wrapped makes no difference.

I've just split the line for this document, it makes the whole thing much easier to read :book:,  but I thought this was a bug worth noting. Thanks for continuing to kick ass! 
## Example Text

```

## In Depth Introduction to the Cyber Kill Chain
[Lockheed Martin | Intelligence-Driven Computer Network Defense Informed by Analysis of Adversary Campaigns and Intrusion Kill Chains](http://www.lockheedmartin.com/content/dam/lockheed/data/corporate/documents/LM-White-Paper-Intel-Driven-Defense.pdf)

> Conventional network defense tools such as intrusion detection systems and anti-virus focus on the vulnerability component of risk, and traditional incident response methodology presupposes a successful intrusion. An evolution in the goals and sophistication of computer network intrusions has rendered these approaches insufficient for certain actors. A new class of threats, appropriately dubbed the “Advanced Persistent Threat” (APT), represents well-resourced and trained adversaries that conduct multi-year intrusion campaigns targeting highly sensitive economic, proprietary, or national security information. These adversaries accomplish their goals using advanced tools and techniques designed to defeat most conventional computer network defense mechanisms. Network defense techniques which leverage knowledge about these adversaries can create an intelligence feedback loop, enabling defenders to establish a state of information superiority which decreases the adversary’s likelihood of success with each subsequent intrusion attempt. Using a kill chain model to describe phases of intrusions, mapping adversary kill chain indicators to defender courses of action, identifying patterns that link individual intrusions into broader campaigns, and understanding the iterative nature of intelligence gathering form the basis of intelligence-driven computer network defense
(CND). Institutionalization of this approach reduces the likelihood of adversary success, informs network defense investment and resource prioritization, and yields relevant metrics of performance and effectiveness. The evolution of advanced persistent threats necessitates an intelligence-based model because in this model the defenders mitigate not just vulnerability, but the threat component of risk, too.

## Responses
![](http://blandin

```
## Screen Shot

![Screen Shot 2013-03-12 at 12 40 50 AM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/44774/247241/717cf79a-8acf-11e2-8c6a-80371a5f4dd8.png)

data.title: Markdown previews appear in a split pane
data.body:
This is the first feature to leverage the power of the new generic panes.

![Screen Shot 2013-03-11 at 5 39 19 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1789/246564/43ab8248-8aa5-11e2-83ca-3dd11ae61511.png)

data.title: Invisibly add newline to end of file
data.body:
Emacs and Vim ensure the last character in a file is always `\n`. Atom doesn't do this:

```
$ cat new-file.vim
new file
$ cat new-file.atom 
new file$
```

This would make a nice setting (enabled by default) because in practice you usually want a newline at the end of files.

data.title: Add mustache syntax highlighter
data.body: Files ending in `.mustache`, `.handlebars`, and  `.hbs` (the extension required by [handlebars_assets](https://github.com/leshill/handlebars_assets)) should use a mustache syntax highlighter.

data.title: Hide text until syntax highlighting finishes
data.body:
When I open atom and it loads a large file I see text without syntax highlighting for a few seconds:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2/245094/8e30b650-8a76-11e2-83fa-7f63b4978b31.png)

It'd be nice to show a spinner or just hide text until highlighting is finished so Atom feels faster.

data.title: Selection gets stuck when toggling dev console
data.body: Right click somewhere in the editor and click 'Toggle Dev Tools' then move your mouse around. It's as if you're holding the mouse button down - selection follows your cursor - but you aren't holding any buttons down.

data.title: Bulleted Lists in Markdown keep indenting
data.body:
![LittleSnapper](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1396/245072/e693ea0c-8a75-11e2-96be-e254766e6a83.png)

Type Bullet, hit Enter, indented +1

data.title: Toggle tree view key command stopped working
data.body:
"Tree View: Toggle" works via `meta-p` but fails when I try to invoke it directly with `meta-\`. Nothing happens.

Is there a way to see what event a key combination is bound to? I don't have `meta-\` in my custom keymap, not sure what is overriding it or if it's just broken.

Noticed that it's bound to `meta-\\` at https://github.com/github/atom/blob/7c47b7f8d4/src/packages/tree-view/keymaps/tree-view.cson#L2 - is that right? When I change it to `meta-\` it still doesn't work.

data.title: The CSON library requires the underscore-extensions library
data.body: I was trying to hook into atom's grammer loading stuff and dump the plist to CSON, but it was failing because the underscore library didn't have a `multiplyString` function. It looks like that function is defined in the `underscore-extensions` library. Adding the `require 'underscore-extensions'` at the top of the CSON library fixed it.

data.title: pressing TAB next to end replaced end with __END__
data.body: This seems like strange behavior.

data.title: fs.list('/') is busted
data.body:
I think this is actually an issue in `$native.traverseTree`, but I didn't want to dig any deeper.

```
> fs = require('fs')
# => dat fs object

> fs.list('/')
# => ["/DS_Store",  "/pplications", "/olumes", ...]
```

The leading slash is correct, but it's killing the first letter of the name of each child. I worked around this in https://github.com/atom/pathology/commit/9695096156bde139c0cc2e3d9ff936db5892f2fd by using `//`, which stops dropping letters but is still ugly:

```
> fs.list('//')
# => ["//.DS_Store",  "//Applications", "//Volumes", ...]
```

In fact, any number of leading `/` will make the first letter stop dropping. I suspect this has something to do with cross-platform (esp. Windows' drive letters) support, but I'm just a simple caveman.

data.title: Merge dev into master
Editor stats blocks visibility of new file/move file input box
data.body:
![Screen Shot 2013-03-08 at 9 36 40 AM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/296432/236004/d06d9902-87d3-11e2-83b2-51d1bcfdba07.png)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Turn on editor stats `cmd-alt-s`
2. In the sidebar, press the `a` key to add a file.
3. The filename input appears behind the editor stats.

What should happen:

Either the filename input pane should probably appear in front of the editor stats, or the editor stats and status bar should be moved upwards to make room for the 100% width input pane below.

data.title: cmd-shift-w doesn't prompt to save dirty buffers
Bad/no syntax highlighting for Perl/PHP files
data.body:
The Perl and PHP tmbundles are shipped in the vendor directory of Atom, and Atom is aware of the content type appropriate, however the tmbundle doesn't appear to be working for these languages' syntax highlighting.

Perl appears to get rendered with Ruby's highlighting rules, which causes a highlighting error with symbol names, and PHP is not highlighted at all:

![Screen Shot 2013-03-07 at 4 31 44 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1882/234737/338986a4-877f-11e2-8f1c-0ae7a114762f.png)

![Screen Shot 2013-03-07 at 4 32 17 PM](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1882/234741/4a8f09e6-877f-11e2-9da7-c2bccbeae45d.png)

No errors in the javascript console.

data.title: cmd-t stuck 'Indexing…`
data.body:
I closed Atom on accident and reopened using `atom .`

Now when I reopen `github/github` `cmd-t` is stuck with "Indexing…"

This happened once before, the way I fixed it was to rerun `rake install` after pulling latest dev branch.

data.title: remember full-screen state
data.body: Native app uncanny valley thing, I think. Apps with full-screen support remember the full-screen state of the main window when they're exited and preserve it for restart. It'd be cool if Atom did this too. I've faked it for myself right now with an `atom.toggleFullScreen()` as the first command in my `~/.atom/user.coffee`, but I'd like to not do that.

data.title: Only allow one full-screen window
data.body:
Having multiple full-screen Atom windows is really, really confusing. Try it out:
1. Be full-screen in a single window
2. Press `M-n`
3. flip back and forth between the windows a bit

I think that new windows created when there's already a full-screen window are almost always gonna be for separate task-based actions, like editing config. I don't think that Atom should open new windows as full-screen.

data.title: Node support
data.body:
:rotating_light: Not ready to be merged :rotating_light: 

The main goal of this branch is to switch to [cefode](https://github.com/zcbenz/cefode) and pull out native code already in Atom into npms.
# Phase 1
- [x] Pull out [ctags npm](https://github.com/atom/node-ctags)
- [x] Put out [oniguruma npm](https://github.com/atom/node-oniguruma)
- [x] Pull out [git npm](https://github.com/atom/node-git)
- [x] Remove internal ChildProcess and use node's instead
- [x] Migrate `fs` to use node's APIs instead of `$native`
- [x] Use underscore node module
- [x] Use coffee-script node module
- [x] Use d3 node module
- [x] Rename atom's `fs` to `fs-utils`
- [x] Extend node's `require` to support the coffee cache
- [ ] Migrate heavy IO web worker tasks to use async IO instead
# Phase 2
- [ ] Move cefode-\* repositories to Atom organization
- [ ] Don't worry about supporting multi-threading
- [ ] Put all modifications from upstream on a `cefode` branch that's rebased on top of `master`, with nice explanatory commit messages. There should be a clear separation of upstream code and changes.
- [ ] Upgrade to node 0.10

data.title: How do I live in Atom all day?
data.body:
This is more of a discussion piece than anything else. Please close it, but I wanted to drop it somewhere for posterity.

My editor isn't per-project or per-file. It's not something I open up a new instance or window of when I want to edit something. Instead, it's my primary interface to my computer. I open my editor at the beginning of every single day, make it full-screen, create two vertical panes (because that's what my brain likes) and often don't leave it for 12 hours. Sometimes my editor (a single full-screen window) stays open for days.

This is, of course, an artifact of living with Emacs for so many years. Emacs is my operating system, and I'd love to be able to feel the same way about Atom.

The stuff that currently makes it harder for me to feel comfortable is filed in a bit more detail as #376, #377, #378, #379 #380, and #381.

:heart:

data.title: How do I open a file from elsewhere in a pane?
data.body:
I work on many, many projects simultaneously, but generally I rock a full-screen, two-vertical-pane, single instance of my editor. I'll very often want to have a file from `github/github` open in the left pane and, say, a file from `github/dat-science` open in the right.

I'd love to have a version of the `M-t` (maybe `M-T` or something) that gives me a fuzzy _path navigator_ instead of an in-project finder.

DANGER: BULLSHIT AHEAD

If I try it out in my head, it goes a little something like this:
1. Press `M-T` for the path navigator
2. Get a popup like the normal `M-t` fuzzy finder, but the entry field is pre-populated with the directory of the last active file, e.g., `~/github/github/`
3. fuzzy finding on files and directories one level deep. pressing `enter` on a directory just adds it to the path. you can delete to move up in the directory hierarchy, natch

This would let me quickly load files from anywhere, which would be awesome. There's tons of room for refinements and wonderful experience here. This could also be a potential solution for #379: If I end up navigating to a nonexistent file it could be created and opened.

This is something I want pretty badly, so I'm 100% happy to hack on this if y'all give me your feelings on the idea and maybe a little pointer to get started.

data.title: How do I unsplit panes?
data.body:
Splitting panes is easy: I got `C-|` and `C--` into my fingers quickly. What's hard for me is unsplits. Currently it looks like I have to `M-w` until I've closed every tab in the pane, at which point it goes away.

The problem for me is that I don't use tabs, and I don't think of files being open in a pane. I think of them as being open in _Atom_ and displayed in a pane when I ask for 'em.

When I think about unsplitting I don't connect it to the idea of closing files at all. I'd love it if unsplitting was a pane-level concern like splitting is.
